abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Economic and Financial
            Adjustment Loan (EFAL) Project's outcome was rated as
            satisfactory. The following lessons learned derived from
            interviews with Bank staff, government counterparts, and
            other stakeholders. 1) It has become clear in countries in
            financial crisis that a high priority is to pursue
            legislation that enhances loan collectability. 2) Reform
            programs should not exceed over tax implementation capacity.
            3) Achieving legal reform within the framework of emergency
            lending operations requires two elements: a) dealing with
            the immediate problems through emergency decrees and b)
            concretely reforming the legal framework and implementation
            capacity so that the future need for emergency decrees is
            reduced. 4) Broader participation in drafting reforms might
            slow implementation in the short-run, but pays off in the
            long-run. 5) Bank participation in the legal reform should
            be broader. 6) Technical assistance, especially grant-funded
            assistance, is an extremely useful catalyst to implement
            reform program components. 7) Gaps in the reform program,
            such as between EFAL II and the planned EFAL III, can have
            costs. 8) Restructuring is an iterative process. 9) Although
            poverty estimates were lower than expected, targeting
            remained an important feature of the fiscal stimulus. 10) In
            an institution with limited capacity for poverty targeting,
            the simplest program, that is decentralized, may be the best.
